Literature Review: Wildlife crime, particularly poaching and illegal wildlife trade, has emerged as a critical global issue threatening biodiversity and ecosystem stability. This literature review explores the application of forensic techniques, with a focus on genetic methods, in combating wildlife crime and their role in legal proceedings.The escalation of wildlife crime has been well-documented in recent years. Nellemann et al. (2014) reported that the illegal wildlife trade has grown into a multi-billion dollar industry, often interlinked with other forms of organized crime. This surge in wildlife crime has had devastating effects on biodiversity, pushing numerous species to the brink of extinction. For instance, Wittemyer et al. (2014) found that poaching accounted for an estimated 75% of African elephant population decline between 2009 and 2013.In response to this crisis, the application of forensic techniques in wildlife crime investigations has gained significant traction. Ogden et al. (2009) highlighted the importance of DNA-based methods in wildlife forensics, noting their potential to identify species, determine geographic origin, and even link evidence to specific individuals. These genetic tools have proven particularly valuable in cases involving endangered species protected under international agreements such as CITES (Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora).One of the primary applications of wildlife forensics is species identification. Linacre and Tobe (2011) described various DNA-based methods for species identification, including DNA barcoding and mitochondrial DNA analysis. These techniques have been successfully employed in numerous cases, allowing investigators to determine the species of origin for seized wildlife products, even when morphological identification is challenging or impossible.Geographic origin determination is another crucial aspect of wildlife forensics. Wasser et al. (2015) demonstrated the power of DNA-based geographic assignment in elephant ivory trafficking cases. By analyzing DNA from seized ivory and comparing it to a reference database of elephant populations, they were able to pinpoint the geographic origins of poached elephants, providing valuable intelligence for law enforcement efforts.Individual identification through DNA profiling has also proven invaluable in wildlife crime investigations. Kitpipit et al. (2012) developed a set of microsatellite markers for individual identification in tigers, which has been instrumental in linking seized tiger parts to specific poaching incidents and tracking the trade routes of tiger products.The admissibility and interpretation of forensic evidence in court proceedings is a critical consideration in wildlife crime cases. Johnson et al. (2014) emphasized the importance of standardized protocols and quality assurance measures in wildlife forensic laboratories to ensure the reliability and credibility of evidence presented in court. They noted that the establishment of the Society for Wildlife Forensic Science has been instrumental in promoting best practices and professionalism in the field.Recent technological advancements have further enhanced the capabilities of wildlife forensics. Ahlers et al. (2017) discussed the potential of next-generation sequencing technologies in wildlife forensics, highlighting their ability to generate large amounts of genetic data quickly and cost-effectively. These technologies offer promising avenues for developing more comprehensive reference databases and improving the resolution of geographic assignment methods.The integration of forensic evidence into legal proceedings has led to several high-profile convictions in wildlife crime cases. Dalton and Kotze (2011) described a case in South Africa where DNA evidence was crucial in securing a conviction for rhino poaching. The ability to link seized rhino horn to a specific poaching incident provided compelling evidence that helped sway the court's decision.Despite these advances, challenges remain in the field of wildlife forensics. Iyengar (2014) identified several obstacles, including the need for more comprehensive reference databases, the complexity of interpreting mixed DNA samples, and the difficulties in standardizing methods across different laboratories and jurisdictions.In conclusion, forensic techniques, particularly those based on genetic analysis, have become indispensable tools in the fight against wildlife crime. As poaching and illegal wildlife trade continue to threaten global biodiversity, the further development and application of these forensic methods will be crucial in supporting law enforcement efforts and securing convictions in wildlife crime cases. Future research should focus on expanding reference databases, improving the resolution and reliability of geographic assignment methods, and developing standardized protocols to ensure the admissibility of forensic evidence in court proceedings worldwide.
